pros: Senior Management that is supportive and innovative.
cons: Long term employees who cannot embrace change.

pros: the union is the best thing that could have happened to this company
cons: the last review here said that long term staff are the Cons because they can't deal with changes and being held accountable. that person is somewhat right. Change is always good, when it's for the betterment of the clients/customers and staff. A 30% wage cut is not a change that's easy to deal with. Also, being held accountable for things you have no control over, or because there are no policies and or procedures in place for most things is also not easy to get used to. Senior management should be busy working on policies and procedures instead of working so hard on getting rid of people. long term employees don't quit because of change. They would have gone through lots of change over the time they've been with the company. Clients don't call the government and have them start investigations because the company is so great to them. They do it, because the changes affect them negatively as well. The housing minister doesn't on regular basis address tenants on regular basis in writing unless there is a serious concern. Funny, one of the questions in here asks if I would recommend this company to a friend. LOL NOT EVEN TO MY ENEMIES.

pros: There are no pros. Google CEO Jennie Denaka’s name and see what kind of “Horror Show” she created for seniors in BC. This woman has no conscience and no heart.
cons: Their largest building Murdoch Manor is infested with bed bugs, cockroaches, scabies and mice.

pros: TPFA does recognize it needs to change its culture for the better.
cons: There are unqualified individuals sitting in senior management positions. The issue this creates when a company wants to change, is that the company cannot actually provide any direction or support for changes - because the changes are not understood by the people responsible for making those decisions. Nobody wants to own decisions because the people being told to own decisions are the wrong people. It creates confusion, division, internal politics, and a very unhealthy, unproductive work environment. Change cannot grow out of the current org structure at head office. The employee turnover numbers speak for themselves.

review_title: Toxic Environment, Terrible Management, Awful Experience
pros:
Average to only slightly-below-average pay and benefits. 

Sometimes, you get a real opportunity to help people who need it. However, your efforts will never be recognized, appreciated, or even understood by management.
cons:
This actually used to be an OK organization to work for (I was there for just under 5 years). 

However, the new and current management that took over around the end of 2020 has made things unbelievably bad, and the Board of Directors seems happy to support them / prop them up. It's a baffling and consistently frustrating mess that makes for a terrible way to spend your workdays, 

If you actually decide to work for TPFA, you can expect to see all of the following, likely within your first few weeks: 

Incompetent, unprofessional, insecure, unethical, and unbelievably poor management (especially senior management).

Zero respect for you as an employee and a human being. If you try to take initiative, you might face the wrath of the very insecure personalities in senior management.

Terrible communication with confusing and poorly written emails / orders from management, as well as multiple management  people talking about multiple different things and issuing multiple conflicting orders and then belittling staff when they seek clarification.

Rampant cronyism (no opportunities for advancement unless you are a good buddy of a manager / director). 

Toxic environment (at all sites) which is more-or-less the result of a senior management and Board of Directors that seems to view employees as nuisances that can be ridiculed and, sometimes, punished/reprimanded for taking initiative, bringing ideas forward, making suggestions, questioning unethical behavior, refusing unsafe work, etc. 

I also learned that having this organization on a resume is  a BIG liability because the organization's reputation is very, very poor. It's actually quite stunning to see how poorly they are viewed in the community.

I couldn't ethically recommend working at this organization to my worst enemy. Unless you are simply desperate for cash, save your dignity and look elsewhere. I'd hate to see anyone have to experience what I (and many, many others) have experienced at Trinity Place Foundation of Alberta.

pros: Great team work, collaboration, Senior Management team is respectful, the employees are multicultural, work-life balance, flexibility, everybody is helping each other, competitive salary and benefits
cons: Changes may be stressful for some whose routines are affected, but for me, if it's for the betterment of the organization and it's stakeholders, changes are good.

review_title: No longer a good company to work for
pros: Challenging environment, you won't get bored.
cons: The new leadership under the new CEO Jennie Deneka has zero respect for staff whom she is free to bully and belittle without any repercussion from the Board.

pros: The guys I work with directly are nice. Seniors are worth it.
cons: The new chief has fired or forced out almost 1/4 of the staff. You Google her and her goals are pretty clear. Money is all that matters. Managers are not allowed to paint tenants apartment. These buildings are going downhill fast. Sad to see. My aunt used to live here and loved it. No way I would let her now. Some managers can’t even stay ahead of the bedbugs. Its all going to crap.

pros: Coworkers and tenants are the best
cons: Close door policy by social workers team

pros:
Working with the tenants.
Supportive team environment.
